description: Fourth pass of intellectual genealogy: analyzes what rhetorical, analytical, and logical function the evolution of each idea serves within the current work. Asks not just 'how did this idea change?' but 'what does the change DO for the current argument?'
deprecated_reason: Replaced by genealogy_synthesis chain (Phase 6 migration). Passes 3-6 collapsed into single chain.
researcher_question: What function does the evolution of this conceptual apparatus serve within the current work?

functional_analyses.idea_name: string - concise name of the idea

functions_served.function_type: legitimation | authority_claim | scope_expansion | framework_foundation | problem_redefinition | audience_shift | theoretical_bridge
functions_served.description: string - how this function operates in the current work
functions_served.evidence: string - textual evidence for this functional claim

functional_analyses.conditions_of_possibility: string - how the author's prior work on this idea made the current argument possible
functional_analyses.what_would_be_impossible_without: string - what the author couldn't claim in the current work without the prior work history
functional_analyses.psychological_dimension: string - optional biographical or psychological reading of the evolution

canonical_schema.overarching_pattern: string - what the sum of all functional analyses reveals about the author's intellectual project as a whole

dominant_function_types: string - most common function types across all ideas

extraction.core_question: What work does the evolution of this idea do for the current argument?
extraction_steps: FOR EACH IDEA WITH EVOLUTION: Review the evolution timeline and synthesis from Pass 3
IDENTIFY FUNCTIONS: Ask what the evolution DOES for the current work — does it legitimate, establish authority, expand scope, bridge theories, redefine problems, or shift audience?
ASSESS CONDITIONS OF POSSIBILITY: Determine how the prior work history enabled claims that would otherwise be unavailable
COUNTERFACTUAL TEST: Ask what the author COULDN'T argue if they didn't have the prior work history
CONSIDER PSYCHOLOGICAL DIMENSION: Optionally, offer a biographical or psychological reading of why the evolution took this path
SYNTHESIZE OVERARCHING PATTERN: Across all ideas, what does the overall functional picture reveal about the author's intellectual project?

key_fields.functions_served: What argumentative work the evolution does
key_fields.conditions_of_possibility: How prior work enables current claims

extraction.special_instructions: This pass requires deep interpretive work. Do not just describe the evolution — analyze what it ACHIEVES. Think about this from the author's strategic position: what does having this intellectual history allow them to do that a newcomer could not? Consider both conscious strategy and unconscious patterns.

consolidation_rules: Group by function type to reveal patterns
Rank by strength of enabling relationship
Flag ideas where prior work constrains rather than enables

id_examples.to: 'Automation thesis' functions as legitimation + authority_claim: prior empirical work authorizes current theoretical speculation

concretization.naming_guidance: Use idea name with primary function type
